image.altText: A photo collage

props.synopsis: One photojournalist follows the lives of Warumungu traditional owners in Jurnkkurakurr (Tennant Creek) as they detail their ambitious way out of a centuries-long housing crisis.

title.children: Overcrowding and 'heat caves' plague these communities. They're now bringing home back to Country

image.altText: Sarah Maculans sits next to a guide dog.

props.synopsis: Sarah Maculans independently navigates life with her white cane and guide dog Syd, but when it comes to buying sanitary products, she's forced to rely on others for help. Advocates say there are simple steps that companies can take to make products more accessible for people who are blind and vision impaired.

title.children: For blind people like Sarah, navigating period products can be a stressful. But developers say they have a solution

image.altText: Supreme Court justices sitting and standing in black robes in official portrait.

props.synopsis: For the first time since his supporters stormed the Capitol on January 6, Donald Trump returned to meet Republican politicians. The Supreme Court had just given them something to talk about.

title.children: America's Supreme Court just took some heat out of a fight that could have been hard for Trump to win

image.altText: A hand wearing a blue rubber glove holding a small tin full of pouches.

props.synopsis: Nicotine pouches are illegal in Australia, but they've been seized in alarming quantities since the federal government's ban on single-use vapes. Here's why the small sachets have authorities worried.

title.children: Are nicotine pouches the next vape? Authorities warn Australia is being flooded with them

image.altText: Map of Australia with temperature for Friday at 2pm

props.synopsis: Through early next week much of the south-east will wake to temperatures near freezing, and along the ranges minimums should plunge to around -5 degrees Celsius.

title.children: Frigid start to winter for south-east states as Melbourne shivers through coldest day in five years

image.altText: A box for the ordering of candidates in South Australia's First Nations Voice to Parliament elections.

props.synopsis: South Australia's inaugural state-based First Nations Voice to Parliament has met for the first time to appoint its presiding members.

title.children: Two First Nations leaders chosen to steer the way forward for SA's Voice to Parliament

image.altText: Man sits in driver's seat.

props.synopsis: Shareholders also approved a proposal to re-elect his brother, Kimbal Musk, and son of media mogul Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch, as board members.

title.children: Billionaire Elon Musk's record-breaking $US56 billion pay package approved by Tesla shareholders

image.altText: Two boys holding up uniform polo shirts with a bunch of shirts on a rack behind them.

props.synopsis: When Newcastle's Belair Public School introduced a new uniform, it didn't want the old ones to end up in landfill. A plan was hatched to recycle them, and also help a remote Fijian community, cyclonic conditions and all.

title.children: It's estimated each school discards at least 100kg of uniforms a year. Here's what this school did with theirs

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy shake hands with US President Joe Biden.

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy signed the 10-year deal in a spate of G7 actions intended to deter Russian President Vladimir Putin.

title.children: Biden and Zelensky sign 'historic' deal to aid Ukraine's military

image.altText: A shot of a baby, taken from above, as he lays in his mum's arms.

props.synopsis: As an exhausted first-time mum, Galen Elliott says she felt "like her world exploded" when she was told there was a potential problem with her newborn.

title.children: 'It's a controversial topic': Data shows tongue-tie procedures have skyrocketed in 30 years

image.altText: Four women stand in coats and winter jackets outside on a sunny day in a city setting. Three are wearing facemasks

props.synopsis: Women in Japan face a $4,800 fine if they have a sterilisation procedure without their spouse's consent, but there is now a fight to have that changed.

title.children: These women want to be sterilised — they have to fight the law, their country, family and history

image.altText: A Palestinian child sits on top of a pile of matresses on a road.

props.synopsis: The United Nations adds Israel's armed and security forces, Hamas, and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad militant group, along with the Sudanese Armed Forces and rival paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces, for the first time to its list of offenders for violating children's rights.

title.children: For the first time, Israel's military and Hamas are added to a global blacklist of offenders that harm children

image.altText: Mark Wood and three England teammates congratulate each other against Oman at the men's T20 World Cup.

props.synopsis: With Australia's Josh Hazlewood causing a stir in the lead-up to the match, England thrashes Oman with 101 deliveries remaining to keeps its hopes alive at the men's T20 World Cup.

title.children: England takes 19 balls to clinch record T20 World Cup win over Oman as Hazlewood's comments linger

image.altText: A black fly-like insect, a stingless bee, pollinating the yellow stamen of a bright orange long-petalled flower.

props.synopsis: Whether you're interested in the sweet benefits of backyard beekeeping or making your home more appealing to solitary species of native bees, what can you do to attract them to your garden?

title.children: Why native bees might be the best ones for your garden — and how to attract them

image.altText: Digi_INPEX_TN

props.synopsis: There are concerns the NT government is not monitoring the health impacts of a large increase in toxic chemicals — linked to cancer and respiratory problems — from Inpex's Ichthys LNG facility, operating on Darwin's harbour.

title.children: Gas giant Inpex is emitting hazardous chemicals near Darwin's CBD, worrying experts and doctors

image.altText: Victim Borna Kazerani  wearing a black jacket, white shirt, striped navy scarf and glasses

props.synopsis: Borna was punched in the face and kicked in the stomach by a couple with a baby in the car park of a Sunday market in Sydney. The attack and use of homophobic slurs has left the Iranian refugee questioning if he is safe in Australia.

title.children: Ten months after an attack and homophobic slurs at a Sunday market, Borna questions if Australia is safe for him

image.altText: A woman looks down on her work documents with a frown

props.synopsis: Going for a run, socialising, and learning a new hobby – a new research study aims to find out how Australians are recovering from their daily work stresses.

title.children: Watching Netflix 'like treading water' in the fight to recover from workday stresses, expert says

image.altText: A grainy photo of Maria James, sitting next to her young son and holding a sleeping baby in her arms.

props.synopsis: Police say even a small detail could be the missing piece in the puzzle of who killed Melbourne mother Maria James in her book store in 1980.

title.children: Maria James was set to confront a priest on the day she died. Her murder has never been solved

image.altText: close up image of a woman changing a baby's nappy

props.synopsis: Some readers expressed relief and validation to discover the behaviour of avoiding certain tasks or responsibility in the home had a name, while others felt it was more a matter of playing to our strengths in a relationship.

title.children: 'My ex pretended he couldn't pack a dishwasher': Readers share experiences with weaponised incompetence

image.altText: A man wearing a black t-shirt and baseball cap hugs his dog

props.synopsis: Tobias Sahlstorfer has been jailed for at least 23 years for the "tragic, brutal and totally unnecessary" bashing murder of Mark Boyce in January 2017.

title.children: Hells Angels bikie sentenced to life in prison over bashing murder of 'innocent bystander'

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas in suit speaking into microphones in front of a South Australian banner.

props.synopsis: The South Australian government plans to introduce what it describes as "world-leading" laws to ban political parties from receiving electoral donations at a state level but concedes the proposed reforms could be subject to a High Court challenge.

title.children: SA government proposes 'world-leading' laws to ban political parties from receiving electoral donations

image.altText: Middle-aged man standing on the edge of a beautiful oceanic hinterland, bald, grey stubble, grey tee, blue pants, slight smile.

props.synopsis: The decision to jump into the water with a southern right whale 30 years ago made international headlines, but the "awesome" experience came at a cost.

title.children: 'I can see why they made the law': Whale rider reflects on 'thrilling' moment that almost landed him in jail

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu graphic

props.synopsis: The evidence suggests the Greens' claims of a "two-way arms trade" between Australia and Israel is in fact one-way, with Australia importing but not exporting lethal technology from Israel.

title.children: Is Australia sending arms to Israel? No, but imports of Israeli weapons continue

image.altText: Boxes of Mifeprisone tablets are stacked on top of each other on a shelf

props.synopsis: The unanimous decision is the first on abortion since Supreme Court justices overturned Roe vs Wade.

title.children: US Supreme Court strikes out bid to restrict access to abortion pill

image.altText: People walk past a stock market graph in a window.

props.synopsis: Australia's share market is expected to decline on the opening bell, despite the S&P500 and Nasdaq closing on fresh record highs in the US overnight.

title.children: ASX tipped to slip, but Wall St closes on another record high

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Should we expect to see more job losses this year?
Tesla shareholders approve Elon Musk's US$56 billion pay

image.altText: students in school uniform standing on Surfers Paradise beach with their surfboards

props.synopsis: When three-time world surfing champion Mick Fanning was a teenager he trained with his mates. Now Australia's next generation of stars are being mentored, from the age of 12, to become world champions.

title.children: A few decades ago having a surfing coach was uncool. That's no longer the case as the sport changes dramatically

image.altText: Three white male soccer players from England, Italy and Germany spliced together in a single image

props.synopsis: It's been three years since the last men's European Championship, with Italy defeating England in a controversial final. Can the Three Lions break their curse to win the 2024 title? If not, who else is in the running?

title.children: UEFA Men's Euros: Can England break its curse? Or will a magical minnow snatch the crown?

image.altText: An iPhone shows various apps against a black background.

props.synopsis: There are growing calls for a ban on children accessing social media, with support on both sides of politics, but experts are divided.

title.children: Social media age limits might be popular with politicians and parents, but experts warn they aren't simple

image.altText: two elderly indigenous men sit at the front porch of the aged care home

props.synopsis: Halls Creek's aged care home serves a vast area with many Indigenous cultural groups, and now a local Aboriginal health service hopes to boost the facility that's struggled in recent years with compliance breaches.

title.children: Indigenous health service takes over outback town's aged care home after compliance breaches and staffing issues

image.altText: Image of hundreds of sheep being held in an open air shed, waiting for export.

props.synopsis: WA farmers impacted by the proposed ban will have their say in Northam today, after a Canberra hearing heard from animal activists and industry leaders earlier this week.

title.children: Politicians warned to expect anger as live sheep export hearing begins in WA

image.altText: A graphic of a mosque silhouette against a light blue background with moon and stars.

props.synopsis: This weekend is a big one on the Islamic calendar, with Eid al-Adha celebrations planned across the country.

title.children: When is Eid al-Adha this year?

image.altText: A low shot looking up at a sign on the side of Perth Children's Hospital.

props.synopsis: A 37-year-old man will face court charged with the manslaughter of an 11-year-old boy who died after being admitted to Perth Children's Hospital for end-of-life care in 2021.

title.children: Man charged over boy's death three years ago, with police alleging he injured child a decade earlier

image.altText: White airliner aircraft with red tail against blue sky

props.synopsis: Travel is a hot-button issue in the AFL this season, with both WA sides doing what they can to mitigate the burden. Now a researcher, embedded with Super Rugby side the Western Force, explains just how draining the flights can be.

title.children: Some have said the travel factor for WA sporting teams is overstated. This researcher says otherwise

image.altText: Woman in her mid-30s, who is smiling at camera, sits at a dining room table covered in photographs.

props.synopsis: Have you ever found an old photograph and wondered about the people it portrays? Well, photo reuniters do more than just wonder, they connect people to their lost memories.

title.children: How an old photo, curiosity and grief led Jesica to become a photo reuniter

image.altText: Kaylee McKeown pushes over the lane rope

props.synopsis: Kaylee McKeown has nudged the world record to the point of it wobbling precariously on the mantelpiece three times in three different events at the Australian Swimming Trials. And that's great news for Paris.

title.children: Kaylee McKeown 'sharpening the axe' for Paris assault after hat-trick of near misses
